risinfo.booktitle: Companion Animal End of Life Care for the Veterinary Technician

para.emphasis: Veterinary Technology Program, Dalhousie University, Bible Hill, NS, Canada

sect2.title: 7.1 Introduction
sect2.para: Communication is an essential skill for veterinary technicians involved in companion animal end‐of‐life (EOL) care, which can be learned and developed through active practice (seeChapter 6). The elements of successful communication apply to all situations veterinary technicians encounter, but some situations that involve high stakes or differing opinions result in elevated emotional responses on the part of both the clients and the veterinary team ch0018-c7-bib-0001. Many of the conversations involved in EOL care would be considered “difficult.” A difficult conversation can generally be classified as a conversation involving sensitive, emotion‐inducing topics which may cause discomfort or conflict among participants. When caregivers or members of the veterinary team are experiencing grief, anger, guilt, or other disruptive emotions during EOL care, this may interfere with effective communication. Strategic use of core communication skills will help technicians navigate these conversations clearly and confidently. These skills include nonverbal behaviors, asking questions, active listening, and showing empathy. This chapter will demonstrate how to apply these communication techniques to various challenging scenarios.

sect2.title: 7.2 Difficult Clients vs Difficult Situations
sect2.para: It can be tempting to label clients experiencing strong emotional responses or disagreement with the veterinary team as “difficult.” Caregivers may at times be judged by veterinary team members as ignorant, neglectful, demanding, or cheapch0018-c7-bib-0002. These labels dismiss the unique perspectives of the caregivers and have significant impact on the team’s capacity to feel and demonstrate empathy. Rather than viewing caregivers as difficult, technicians may shift their perspective to consider the situation as difficult (see Case Study 7.1).

sidebar.title: Case Study 7.1 Andy and Fozzie
sidebar.para: Andy is a long‐time client of his regular veterinary clinic. He has brought in his 19‐year‐old cat, Fozzie, for euthanasia. As the technician, Maya, discusses the cost of the procedure, Andy becomes visibly upset. His face red, he says loudly, “I’ve been bringing Fozzie here for his whole life and I’ve probably spent enough to pay for that new addition you got last year. You mean to tell me you charge that much to put her down? That’s ridiculous!”

Maya does her best to calm Andy but leaves the interaction feeling very shocked and upset. She seeks out Brandon, a more experienced technician, to share her feelings. “I always thought Andy was a nice guy. I had no idea he was so cheap! He didn’t have to be such a jerk.”

Brandon thoughtfully replies, “It sounds like Andy’s anger really caught you off guard. Andy has been coming here for a long time, and he is a really nice guy. He and Fozzie have had a very special relationship and I’m sure Andy is really struggling with saying good‐bye. He’s been paying a lot for Fozzie’s medication for at least a year as well. It’s a really tough situation.”

Maya listens thoughtfully to Brandon and responds, “You’re right, I shouldn’t have been so quick to call him cheap. He’s always done everything we recommend for Fozzie. I shouldn’t have judged him like that for just one bad experience. I know how hard it is to say good‐bye.”

listitem.para: Can you think of a situation in practice where you have judged a client’s behavior as difficult? How might your perception have impacted your interactions with those clients?
What could Maya do in the future to try to shift her mindset from labelling the client to recognizing the challenge in the situation?

sect2.title: 7.3 Applying Communication Skills to Difficult Conversations
sect2.para: In addition to the skills discussed inChapter 6, there are two communication tools which can be especially helpful in difficult conversations: partnership statements and warning shots.

sect2.title: 7.3.1 Partnership Statements
sect2.para: It is common for the caregivers of EOL pets to feel that their situation is out of their control, leaving them overwhelmed and feeling helpless. The technician can affirm that the caregiver is an essential part of the EOL care team by creating a sense of partnership. Collaborative partnership statements begin with terms such as “We,” “You and I,” “As a team,” or “Together”ch0018-c7-bib-0001. For example, “Together we can create a plan to help Snowball feel more comfortable at home.”

sect2.title: 7.3.2 Warning Shots
sect2.para: EOL conversations often involve the delivery of information that may be upsetting. In these instances a “warning shot” is used to alert the caregiver that there is something difficult to discuss, allowing them time to mentally preparech0018-c7-bib-0001. Examples of warning shots include: “I have something to share that may be distressing for you to hear,” “We need to talk about the changes in Muffin’s condition,” or “I’m afraid I have some bad news today.” Warning shots should always be followed by a pause to allow the client to respond.

sect2.title: 7.4 A Model for End‐of‐Life Conversations
sect2.para: Although each EOL scenario is unique and should be treated as such, it is helpful to have a general plan for how to approach these conversations. The SPIKES model was originally developed for human physicians delivering bad news, and it can be used successfully in veterinary medicine as well [ch0018-c7-bib-0003–ch0018-c7-bib-0005]. The steps of the SPIKES approach are setting, perspective, invitation, knowledge, empathize, summarize, and strategize. They are explained in detail below with identification of the communication skills needed during each part of the process.

sect2.title: 7.4.1 Setting
sect2.para: Consider where EOL conversations will take place. Ideally practices should have a designated “comfort room” designed to promote calm, open communication. Comfort rooms typically are quiet, private spaces with comfortable furniture and adjustable lighting. More information about comfort room design can be found inChapters 11 and 16.

Consider who should be present for the conversationch0018-c7-bib-0004. For example, a distressed caregiver who is alone may wish to invite additional support, while a client with caregiver may not want them included in the conversation.

Establish rapport at the beginning of the conversation. Use open questioning techniques to determine how the caregiver is feeling, followed by reflective statements, and empathy. Acknowledging the difficult nature of the conversation up front can help people feel more at easech0018-c7-bib-0005.

sect2.title: 7.4.2 Perspective
sect2.para: Before providing medical information or guidance in any decision‐making process, it is important to elicit the client’s perspective. Asking open questions allows the client to share their knowledge of the current situation and their goals of care moving forwardch0018-c7-bib-0003. For example, “How is Rex doing now?” and “What concerns do you have?”

It is important to determine how much information the client wants to receive. Some detail‐oriented clients will benefit from a thorough discussion of options, while others prefer a big‐picture approach with just enough information to help them make informed decisions. Technicians can determine this preference with a question like, “At times like this, some people prefer to know all the details while others prefer a broader outline. Which would you prefer?” [ch0018-c7-bib-0003, ch0018-c7-bib-0004].

sect2.title: 7.4.3 Invitation
sect2.para: The technician ensures they are invited to share difficult information by asking for permission from the caregiver [ch0018-c7-bib-0004, ch0018-c7-bib-0005]. This follows smoothly from assessing the level of detail the caregiver wishes to receive, but it is often overlooked. Technicians may simply ask, “Is it alright if I share some information with you now?” Doing so allows the caregiver the opportunity to confirm if they are ready to move forward in the conversation.

sect2.title: 7.4.4 Knowledge
sect2.para: Once the caregiver gives their permission, the technician can proceed to share their knowledge as appropriate to the situation. Although it was originally developed to help with the delivery of bad news, the SPIKES model is appropriate for conversations at all stages of EOL care. This may include information about hospice and palliative care options, quality of life or pain assessment, education on treatment administration, or EOL planning.

Provide information in short, easily understandable statements, or “chunks.” Follow new information with questions like “What questions do you have about what you’ve heard so far?” or “What are your thoughts about what I’ve said?” These are “checks” to ensure the client’s needs are met and they are active partners in the conversation [ch0018-c7-bib-0001, ch0018-c7-bib-0003]. This “chunk and check” method of information delivery is useful in many contexts and is especially helpful in EOL conversations when emotions may make it hard for clients to focus.

sect2.title: 7.4.5 Empathize
sect2.para: Empathy must be demonstrated throughout difficult conversations, starting with rapport building as the setting is created. Use appropriate nonverbal behaviors, maintain compassionate eye contact, and verbalize empathy by acknowledging and supporting the clients' emotions (seeChapter 6 for more information regarding empathy as a communication skill).

sect2.title: 7.4.6 Summarize and Strategize
sect2.para: The final step in the SPIKES model is to summarize the discussion and come to a shared decision on the path forward. Technicians can make suggestions and help the caregiver identify additional support systems as appropriate [ch0018-c7-bib-0003, ch0018-c7-bib-0005]. For example, in the case of a QOL conversation, the technician would provide the selected QOL tools and set a plan for frequency of assessment and communication of those results to the veterinary team. Other examples of strategizing in EOL conversations would be the identification of emergency care options and/or offering of grief support resources. Providing the client with written documentation and access to online resources will ensure they feel supported when they are ready to process additional information on their own.

sect2.title: 7.5 Conflict Resolution
sect2.para: Conflicts may arise during stressful, emotionally charged situations that are often a part of EOL care. This can include conflict among caregivers and other family members, between caregivers and the veterinary team, or among members of the veterinary team. Conflict develops when people perceive that someone else’s actions or beliefs will stop them from getting what they need or want for themselvesch0018-c7-bib-0006. In EOL situations, conflict can occur when the caregiver's desires for their pet’s care are not in alignment with the options offered by the veterinary team, when caregivers or family have different opinions about the animal’s care, or when the cost of care is too expensive for their financial situation. Conflict can also occur within the veterinary team if there is disagreement about ethical case management. Further examples of conflict‐related conversations are found in Section 7.6.

Regardless of the cause, conflict can be damaging to the team‐based relationships needed for successful EOL care and this can impact patient care. Caregivers may lose trust in the veterinary team or even develop feelings of hostility. They may feel excluded from decision making and lose interest in working toward solutionsch0018-c7-bib-0006. Successful, positive resolution of conflict improves patient outcomes and promotes trust and rapport in the veterinary–client relationship. It also safeguards the working environment and wellness of veterinary team members.

Table 7.1
Conflict management communication styles. Source: Adapted from Hendricks ch0018-c7-bib-0007.

entry.para: Competing
Asserting your own needs as the most important
Allows for rapid decision making, especially in emergencies
Does not consider the needs of others who may be negatively impacted
Avoiding
Not discussing conflict‐inducing issues
Provides temporary relief from discomfort, prevents confrontation
Results in issues building up over time, may worsen the eventual conflict
Accommodating
Prioritizing the needs of others as the most important
Leads to rapid conflict resolution with positive results for others

Compromising
Encouraging each side to make concessions in order to find a middle ground
May allow for quick resolution of conflict, useful when time is a constraint

Collaborating

Most likely to result in resolution that benefits everyone

sect2.para: Technicians with a high degree of emotional intelligence (EI) are better equipped to manage conflict. In Chapter 6, self‐awareness was identified as one of the key components in the development of EI. As technicians work to increase self‐awareness, they will benefit from examining their own personal approach to conflict. As with other elements of EI, responding to conflict in a positive way is a skill which can be developed over time. Table 7.1 lists several common conflict resolution communication styles, each with their own benefits and drawbacks ch0018-c7-bib-0007.

para.emphasis: When experiencing conflict, which style of communication is your “go‐to”?
Does your personal style generally result in successful conflict resolution?

sect2.para: When practicing relationship‐based medicine and partnered decision making, the most effective communication style for conflict resolution is collaboration. Gathering everyone’s perspectives and priorities grounds decision‐making in the best interests of everyone involved, especially the animal. The core communication skills that were discussed inChapter 6 are essential tools when working to resolve conflict.

listitem.para: Ask for permission to participate in an in‐depth conversation (e.g. “Would you be willing to discuss this further?”) while recognizing that timing is important. Some conversations may be better deferred until emotions are less intense, if the situation permits.
Actively listen to the other participants and acknowledge their perspectives without judgment. Use reflective statements to demonstrate understanding without signaling agreement ch0018-c7-bib-0006.
Open questioning techniques allow technicians to learn more about the cause of the conflict, while listening for and responding to emotions and nonverbal cues.

Summarize the conversation and propose solutions through the use of partnership statements. When it feels appropriate, thank the other participants for their willingness to work together to find the best solution ch0018-c7-bib-0006.

sect2.title: 7.6.1 Grief
sect2.para: Compassionate communication with grieving clients is the subject of Part IV: Grief and Memorialization. Many sample case studies are provided to help technicians navigate these difficult conversations. As you read through Part IV, look for the core communication skills identified inChapter 6—they are present throughout these cases.

sect2.title: 7.6.2 Delivering Bad News
sect2.para: As technicians develop their roles on EOL care teams, there may be situations in which they are called upon to deliver difficult news to caregivers. While veterinarians have the responsibility to share information related to diagnoses and prognoses, caregivers may reach out to technicians with questions or patient updates that require sensitive communication. Technicians are often responsible for providing caregivers with updates on fees, which can lead to challenging conversations about finances.

The key elements of SPIKES apply when providing caregivers with news that is likely to have a negative impact—emotionally or financially. Use warning shots to allow caregiver(s) time to mentally preparech0018-c7-bib-0003. Follow with the chunk‐and‐check technique to prevent information overload. Regardless of the intelligence, knowledge, or training level of the caregiver, emotions may remove their capacity to think clearly when bad news is being delivered. Information may need to be repeated and should also be written down for later reference to ensure the caregiver has understood and is able to retain the information. Avoid the use of medical jargon and be sure to define any unfamiliar terms that cannot be avoided ch0018-c7-bib-0003 (see Case Study 7.2).

sidebar.title: Case Study 7.2 John and Bolt
sidebar.para: Marla is a technician on the hospice care team for Bolt, a 12‐year‐old Springer Spaniel. Bolt was previously diagnosed with lymphoma and has experienced pleural effusion. The veterinary team performed a thoracocentesis to relieve the clinical signs and Bolt has been doing well since then. Marla visits Bolt and his caregiver John at home once weekly to check in (i.e. assessing respiratory rate, sounds, and effort as well as quality of life) and provide support to John (e.g. assess caregiver burden, educate, and provide emotional support).

During one of Marla’s weekly visits, John shares that Bolt has seemed a bit tired the last couple of days but is otherwise fine. As Marla assesses Bolt, she notes his respiratory rate is increased and he is showing signs of respiratory effort. She also finds that his heart sounds are muffled, and she becomes concerned that the pleural effusion has recurred.

para.phrase: John sits quietly with downcast eyes and says:
Marla uses direct eye contact and leans in to demonstrate empathy:

listitem.para: Thinking about a time when you received bad news, was a “warning shot” provided? If so, did you find it helpful? If not, how might it have impacted your conversation at the time?
In what ways did Marla frame her conversation to ensure she remained within a technician’s scope of practice?

sect2.title: 7.6.3 Anger
sect2.para: Anger is a complex emotional state that can be driven by a variety of underlying feelings such as sadness, fear, uncertainty, and guilt. Caregivers may become angry over financial concerns, disagreements, or poor communication with the veterinary teamch0018-c7-bib-0008. Anger is also a natural part of the grieving process, which is discussed further in Chapter 14. Veterinary team members may also become angry over disagreements or misunderstandings in EOL care. Although it is a common emotional response, the veterinary team may feel poorly equipped to effectively communicate with people demonstrating signs of anger ch0018-c7-bib-0002. While this section will focus on anger in caregivers, the communication skills are the same in team‐based encounters.

People experiencing anger may demonstrate physical and behavioral changes as outlined inTable 7.2. Identifying signs of anger allows technicians to prepare and adjust their communication style with the intent of diffusing the anger before attempting to solve any problems. Interacting with people who are angry can be intimidating and may lead to reactions of anger, defensiveness, or avoidance. Once anger has been identified, technicians should take a moment to assess their own reaction to the situation. Practicing calming techniques like mindfulness can help reduce the effects of negative emotions and allow the technician to continue the encounter in a more neutral state. More information on mindfulness techniques is found in Chapter 17.

Table 7.2

entry.para: Facial flushing Sweating Increased heart rate and respiratory rate Clenched fists Tense muscles
Raised voice or shouting Throwing or breaking things Refusal to make eye contact Withdrawal Physical violence

para.emphasis: Which of the physical and behavioral signs of anger do you experience when you are angry?
What is your “go‐to” response when someone is angry with you?

sect2.para: The key to managing and reducing anger in others is to create a safe situation in which people can share their feelings without judgment. This may involve inviting the caregiver(s) to a private space such as an exam room if they are not already therech0018-c7-bib-0008. The space should promote comfortable, open communication through the availability of seating without barriers. Use open, positive nonverbal cues such as relaxed arms and calm eye contact and welcome the caregiver to share their perspective and listen closely without interruption. Let them “vent” until they are ready to stop on their own. Listen for cues that may indicate other emotions contributing to the anger as well as the caregiver's primary concerns. In many cases anger is the outward manifestation of other emotions.

Once the technician feels they have successfully identified the emotions and perspectives motivating the caregiver's anger, they can follow up with empathy and reflective listening. This should include paraphrasing to confirm they have successfully understood the caregiver's perspectivech0018-c7-bib-0001. For example, “It sounds like you are angry because Freddie’s diagnosis has caught you off guard and you don’t feel your questions have been clearly answered.” Remember that acknowledging the person's feelings does not mean that the technician agrees with their perspective, only that they have identified it. Partnership statements play an important role in building rapport with angry caregivers. “Let’s work together to ensure you have all the information you need to make the best choices for Freddie.” It is hard to maintain anger against someone who is on your team, working with you to find solutions (see Pro Tip 7.1).

sect2.title: 7.6.4 Financial Conflict
sect2.para: Communicating the fees associated with veterinary care is a task that is increasingly falling to technicians. They often have more time to help caregivers understand costs and develop payment strategies while also grasping the medical context of the decision making. Although most of these conversations are straightforward, discussions about money are clouded by societal perception that it is inappropriate to discuss money ch0018-c7-bib-0011. It is possible that many communications about fees will fall into the category of difficult conversations.

sidebar.title: Pro Tip 7.1 Stop, Drop, and Roll
sidebar.para: When you encounter an angry caregiver, take these three steps toward successful resolution:

listitem.para: STOP talking! Listen to the caregiver's perspective.
DROP the need to be right. Even if you are right, telling the caregiver that will not help.
ROLL the caregiver's words right off your back. Remain calm and free of defensiveness.

sidebar.para: Following this plan will help the caregiver become calm and ready to talk, because they feel heard without judgementch0018-c7-bib-0010.

sect2.para: End‐of‐life care often results in increased frequency of appointments, increased medications, and additional costs related to euthanasia and aftercare/memorialization. These factors all increase the frequency of fee‐related conversations. In addition, some caregivers may need to make EOL care decisions from a purely financial standpoint, which may cause moral distress for them and the veterinary team. The good news is that the core communication skills fromChapter 6 and transparency about costs and the value of services will prevent most misunderstandings and conflict regarding finances. When presenting financial plans and options to caregivers, maintain focus on the benefit the product or service will provide to the pet. Avoid making assumptions about what the caregiver will be willing or able to pay ch0018-c7-bib-0011. When caregivers must make decisions that consider their own financial limitations in addition to the welfare of their pet, they may experience moral distress. Technicians play a valuable role in reassuring caregivers that financial limitations are a legitimate concern, and they are making the best choice they can for their pet within their circumstances (see Chapter 8 for more discussion of supporting EOL decision making).

The more stressful the interaction, the more clients value the core communication skills of active listening and empathy as indicators of trustworthiness and reliability in the veterinary teamch0018-c7-bib-0011. Consistently demonstrating empathy through nonverbal behaviors and empathy statements will support smooth, clear communication about finances. Pause often and solicit questions, ensuring caregivers have adequate time to consider and share any concerns (see Case Study 7.3).

sidebar.title: Case Study 7.3 Kamal and Bala
sidebar.para: Kamal brings his 15‐year‐old Toy Poodle, Bala, in for an emergency assessment after she collapses at home. Kamal was provided information about the emergency examination fee on the phone. The veterinarian examines Bala and determines she is stable but requires a workup for diagnosis, including bloodwork, urinalysis, and radiographs. She asks Chastity, her technician, to develop a plan for the fees and review it with Kamal to obtain consent to proceed. Chastity enters the exam room and sees Kamal is seated with Bala on his lap. He is visibly worried. His hand is shaking as he strokes Bala softly and speaks to her in low tones. Chastity takes a seat next to Kamal.

para.phrase: Kamal looks up, his posture relaxing a little as he responds:
Chastity pauses briefly to think about the emotion behind Kamal’s response and reminds herself not to take his anger personally before answering:

sidebar.para: Chastity agrees and together they review the recommendations from the veterinarian with Chastity describing the benefits for Bala related to each procedure. Finally, Kamal approves the bloodwork and urinalysis but elects to wait on the radiographs.

listitem.para: How might the outcome of this conversation have changed if Chastity had reacted defensively to Kamal’s questions about the expense?
Consider the suggested testing (bloodwork, urinalysis, and radiographs) and think about how you would describe the value provided to Bala and Kamal for each test.

sect2.title: 7.6.5 Disagreement Within the Team
sect2.para: The availability of a wide variety of treatment options and the ethical and moral considerations within EOL care may result in disagreements within the veterinary team. There is rarely a right or wrong choice. Instead, decisions must be made with the goal of optimal outcomes for both the animal and caregivers in their unique circumstances. It is possible for technicians in these situations to disagree with the decisions made by veterinarians or other team members. Ultimately, medical recommendations are the responsibility of the veterinarian, but technicians can share valuable insights that will have an impact on these decisions. Often disagreement over medical decisions is related to a lack of sufficient knowledge and understanding of how the decision was reached. Using the techniques identified for conflict resolution, specifically a collaborative approach, will help these conversations proceed more smoothly.

The power dynamic between a veterinarian and a veterinary technician can make these situations some of the most challenging to handle. In conflicts where there is a perceived power imbalance, many people fall back on the avoidance communication style out of fear of negative responses, including potentially being firedch0018-c7-bib-0012. Technicians may feel that their knowledge or opinions should not be shared when they do not align with those of the veterinarian. All the techniques discussed so far come into play when initiating a difficult conversation with a veterinarian or other colleague. Considering SPIKES with a special focus on conflict resolution will ensure technicians are prepared for open, respectful conversation.

listitem.para: Setting: These conversations should be in private spaces, ideally away from uninvolved team members and never in front of caregivers. Choose the timing carefully, when everyone is available to give their undivided attention. Avoid having these conversations when emotions are very strong—take a pause to calm down and plan. Ask permission to ensure the timing is right, and provide a warning shot that this conversation may be difficult. For example, “Dr. Martin, Sophie’s euthanasia was very hard for me today and I have some questions. Would now be a good time to talk?”
Perspective: Use open questioning techniques to learn more about the veterinarian’s perspective. Remain open minded and use reflective statements to ensure understanding.

Invitation: Request permission to share your personal perspective and continue the conversation. For example, “I would like to share with you how I feel about this situation. Would that be alright?”. Remember that veterinarians will have their own emotional responses and capacity to manage conflict, and this invitation allows them to assess if they are prepared to listen further at this time.

Knowledge: Identify the areas of disagreement while avoiding terms that may appear judgmental. Stay focused on the facts of the situation and use “I” statements to express perspective. “I felt that Sophie’s euthanasia may have been premature as she appeared to still have good quality of life.”

Empathy: Throughout the encounter, stay focused on underlying emotional responses. The veterinarian may feel anxious or upset when someone expresses concern about their actions. Acknowledging that this is an uncomfortable feeling using empathy statements can help both parties in the conversation feel better. Technicians should also demonstrate empathy for themselves and recognize that strong emotions are normal in these circumstances. "I can see how difficult it is to have the pressure of these decisions on you, especially when they are being questioned."

Summarize and strategize: The goal of this process is to resolve the conflict in a positive way that may also prevent disagreements of the same nature from occurring in the future. Ideally the conversation might lead toward either agreement on the topic or at least improved understanding of different perspectives. Thank the veterinarian for being willing to engage in the conversation. “I’m glad we had this conversation together. Although I feel I would not have made the same choice as Sophie’s caregivers, I can see why it was a humane decision based on everything you’ve shared. Thank you for talking it through with me.”

sect2.para: Case Study 7.4 provides an additional example of the SPIKES model as it can be used in team communication.

sidebar.title: Case Study 7.4 Diego and Mina
sidebar.para: Diego is an experienced technician working in a companion animal practice who has recently started working some extra shifts at his local emergency and referral center. He has enjoyed seeing emergency and critical care cases and feels his new knowledge will help in his regular job.

Diego is at work with his companion animal veterinarian, Dr. Beals. They are seeing Mina, a 15‐year‐old Siamese with chronic renal failure. Mina has been doing well on medication, but her caregivers have brought her in for an examination because her appetite has been decreasing steadily despite her antinausea medication and subcutaneous fluids. She has been inappetent for two days. Dr. Beals examines Mina and determines she is doing well other than her lack of interest in food. He recommends buying a few different flavors of canned food and suggests that the owners spend time coaxing her to eat by heating it up and offering her small, frequent spoonfuls.

After the appointment, Diego is concerned. He has seen the positive effects of feeding tube placement for cats in renal failure at his other job and he wonders why Dr. Beals did not offer this as an option for Mina, especially when the clients expressed their doubt that coax feeding would be successful. Diego decides to approach Dr. Beals with his question at the end of the day.

listitem.para: What communication techniques did Diego use to help this conversation progress smoothly?
If you were in Diego’s shoes, what elements of this conversation would you find most challenging? What strategies could you use to reduce your discomfort?

sect2.para: There may be instances where technicians are asked to participate in activities which they feel go against their own personal moral code. An example would be the case of “convenience euthanasia,” when the decision to euthanize may not appear to be driven by the medical needs or best interests of the pet. While these situations are upsetting and can cause division within the veterinary team, maintaining an open and inquiring mind can help. It is not appropriate to question the veterinarian’s decision in front of caregivers, but technicians can and should respectfully ask for more information privately when they are being asked to perform a task they do not support. If there is not sufficient time to discuss the case, or an understanding cannot be reached that alleviates the technician’s concerns, it is possible to decline to participate. This must be done professionally and respectfully. “Based on the information I have, I’m not comfortable assisting with Timber’s euthanasia today.” Avoid making statements that judge the actions of the veterinarian or other team members and keep the focus on your own personal beliefs and feelings. An event like this requires follow‐up at a time when team members have the capacity to discuss it clearly and calmly. Approach these conversations like any other difficult conversation: Consider the elements of SPIKES and remain open minded and willing to hear the perspectives of others. It is hoped that this will be a rare situation. If a technician feels that their moral and ethical code is repeatedly challenged, it may be time to look for an environment more aligned with their beliefs.

sect2.title: 7.6.6 Disagreement Among Caregivers
sect2.para: There are many decisions required during EOL care regarding palliative treatment options, humane euthanasia, supported‐natural death, body care, and memorialization. When a pet has multiple caregivers or family members involved in decision making, it is possible that disagreements will arise. Technicians may offer to help in situations where caregivers are divided in their opinions about the best path forward. Clients must be willing to participate in a conversation about the disagreement, so technicians will need to seek consent as an important first step. For example, “It sounds like there may be a disagreement about whether to give Sadie subcutaneous fluids. Would you both be willing to talk that through together with me?” This approach both identifies the issue and seeks permission to continue.

After permission is granted, begin by inviting the caregivers to share their thoughts in a calm manner, without interruption. For example, “Sue, why don’t you start by telling us how you feel, and when you are done Peter can share. We want to work together to make sure we all understand.” The use of partnership statements can reduce the feeling of adversity, reminding everyone they are working together as a team in the best interests of the pet. The technician’s role is to help clarify and summarize the perspectives of each caregiver and provide medical information as needed. When mediating conflict between caregivers, the technician must remain a neutral party at all times, regardless of their personal beliefs about the situationch0018-c7-bib-0013.

Use the active listening skills of reflective and summary statements to clarify each caregiver's perspective and ensure they feel they are being accurately heard and understood. Once the cause of the dispute is clear, a summary statement presenting both sides of the disagreement can be made. For example, “Based on what you’ve shared, Sue feels that subcutaneous fluids will provide Sadie with improved quality of life and prolong the time before a decision needs to be made about euthanasia. Peter is concerned that the stress of administering the fluids will actually reduce Sadie’s quality of life and damage the special bond you all share. Does that sound right?”

Once the caregivers feel that their perspectives are clear, it is time to work toward a solution through finding common ground and proposing options that may work for both sides. Consider and validate the emotions of the caregivers while suggesting solutions that support the best care for the pet. For example, “At this point we haven’t tried to give Sadie subcutaneous fluids at all, so we don’t really know how stressful she will find the experience. Would you be open to us trying them once to see how she reacts to the procedure? That may help us reach a decision.” Ensure both participants have an opportunity to weigh in on proposed solutions and continue to adjust the plan until they have ideally reached agreement. Once a plan is agreed upon, review it once more and give a final opportunity for the caregivers to respond before implementing the plan. Remaining calm and impartial will help the caregivers work through their disagreement in an open and productive way (seeCase Study 7.5).

sidebar.title: Case Study 7.5 Myrna, Grace, and Jazz
sidebar.para: Myrna and Grace have brought their 12‐year‐old Border Collie, Jazz, into the clinic, because she has been very lethargic for several days. Following a thorough workup, the veterinarian determines that Jazz has a splenic mass bleeding into her abdomen. Myrna and Grace agree that surgery is not the best option for them due to Jazz’s age and their concern about the level of invasiveness and stress with recovery. They elect to take her home overnight to say goodbye, returning the next day for euthanasia. Angela is the technician on the case, and she sits with the couple to discuss the euthanasia procedure and determine their preferences.

para.phrase: Grace, who has been very quiet throughout the appointment, suddenly says:
Grace begins to cry and Angela passes her a tissue before saying:

sidebar.para: Myrna and Grace agree, and Angela provides them with the information they need to make a decision. Grace decides to be present with Jazz until sedation occurs and then she will decide if she wants to stay for the actual euthanasia.

listitem.para: In what ways did Angela demonstrate empathy throughout this scenario? What impact do you think this empathy had on Myrna and Grace?

Think of a situation in which caregivers disagree, and you have strong feelings that one caregiver is right, and the other is wrong. What techniques could you use to remain neutral and help them reach a decision?

sect2.title: 7.7 Assess for Success
sect2.para: Navigating difficult conversations requires a solid foundation of core communication skills and a willingness to try, which includes making mistakes and learning from them. When interactions do not go smoothly, it is important to spend some time on honest self‐reflection and consider if different communication strategies could work better in similar situations in the future. Soliciting feedback from other skilled communicators and bringing scenarios to communication rounds will also support growth and learning. Technicians should also recognize that it is possible to do everything “right” and still not have the desired outcome, because communication always involves other people! Use each interaction as a learning opportunity and keep applying the skills consistently.

listitem.para: Difficult conversations are those that may cause discomfort or conflict for participants.
Use partnership statements to build trust and provide “warning shots” to help recipients of bad news prepare themselves.
EOL conversations can be structured using the SPIKES model, paying special attention to setting, client perspectives, “chunk and check” knowledge delivery, and empathy.
Developing a collaborative communication style for conflict resolution can benefit all participants.

Core communication skills can be applied to various difficult conversations, including delivering bad news, managing anger, discussing money, and navigating disagreements within the veterinary team or between caregivers.
Thoughtful self‐reflection and debriefing following difficult conversations will promote growth of communication skills and increase successful outcomes.
